In summary, we have investigated topological properties of the bulk and surface band structures of bismuth. We show that bismuth is a TCI with multiple nontrivial topological invariants. In the first order, bismuth features unpinned Dirac surface states on the

surfaces that are protected by their twofold rotational symmetries. These unpinned Dirac surface states would be amenable to direct imaging via photoemission spectroscopy. In the second order, bismuth features two sets of independent topological helical hinge states. The first set is protected by the twofold rotational symmetries whereas the second set is protected by space inversion symmetry. Our study thus provides a comprehensive picture of the rich band topology of bismuth, which is arguably the most important element involved in the field of topological materials.
